statement.tex: %text Find the value of $\lambda$ so that the lines $\dfrac{1-x}{3}=\dfrac{7y-14}{2\lambda}=\dfrac{5z-10}{11}$ and $\dfrac{7-7x}{3\lambda}=\dfrac{y-5}{1}=\dfrac{6-z}{5}$ are perpendicular to each other. %

step.context: L_1: \dfrac{1-x}{3}=\dfrac{7y-14}{2\lambda}=\dfrac{5z-10}{11} \\ L_2: \dfrac{7-7x}{3\lambda}=\dfrac{y-5}{1}=\dfrac{6-z}{5} \\ %text What are the direction ratios of the above lines? %
step.reason: %text To get the correct direction ratios the equation of the line must be in the form % \dfrac{x-x_1}{a}=\dfrac{y-y_1}{b}=\dfrac{z-z_1}{c}

step.context: \begin{array}{cccc} L_1: & -3, & \frac{2}{7}\lambda, & \frac{11}{5} \\ L_2: & -\dfrac{3}{7}\lambda, & 1, & -5 \end{array} \\ %text The direction ratios of two lines are given above. If $L_1\perp L_2$, what is $\lambda$? %
step.reason: %text If two lines are perpendicular, their direction ratios follow the relation $a_1a_2+b_1b_2+c_1c_2=0$ % \begin{align} &\left(-3\right)\left(-\dfrac{3}{7}\lambda\right) +\left(\dfrac{2}{7}\lambda\right)+\left(\dfrac{11}{5}\right)\left(-5\right)=0 \\ \implies& \dfrac{9}{7}\lambda+\dfrac{2}{7}\lambda-11=0 \\ \implies& \lambda=7 \end{align}
